byline.contributor: Eric Lichtblau reported from Washington, and Katie Benner from San Francisco. Matt Apuzzo contributed reporting from Washington, Sewell Chan from London, and Paul Mozur from Hong Kong.
byline.original: By ERIC LICHTBLAU and KATIE BENNER

abstract: Order by federal magistrate judge commanding Apple to unlock iPhone used by attacker in San Bernardino, Calif, shooting has set off intense public battle between Obama administration and company, which could have wide-ranging legal implications over balance between national security and privacy; Apple chief executive Tim Cook has publicly bristled at order, and sends letter to all company's customers warning of government's actions.
lead_paragraph: Timothy D. Cook, Apple’s chief, said the government’s request to bypass security on the phone used by Syed Rizwan Farook had “chilling” implications.

headline.main: Apple Fights Order to Unlock San Bernardino Gunman’s iPhone
headline.print_headline: As Apple Resists, Encryption Fray Erupts in Battle

snippet: Timothy D. Cook, Apple’s chief, said the government’s request to bypass security on the phone used by Syed Rizwan Farook had “chilling” implications.
